Method Detail

getEulerAngles

public static double[] getEulerAngles(Vector3D_d u,
                                      Vector3D_d v)
Return an array containing a set of "Euler angles" representing a rotation that takes the orthonormal basis vectors i,j,k into another set of orthonormal basis vectors u,v,n. Only the basis vectors u,v are taken as arguments since the "n" vector is calculated internally as u X v. "v" is then recalculated as n X u, in case v was not originally perpendicular to "u". All vectors will be normalized internally. The angles of rotation are to be applied as follows: 1. Rotate about the positive z-axis by phi 2. Rotate about the positive x-axis by chi 3. Rotate about the positive z-axis by omega NOTE: All rotations follow a right hand rule and the coordinate system is assumed to be right handed. Rotation angles are returned in degrees.

Parameters:
u - Vector giving the direction that the basis vector "i" maps to.
v - Vector giving the direction that the basis vector "j" maps to. In principle, this should be perpendicular to u, it at least must not be collinear with u.
Returns:
The Euler angles are returned in an array euler[], with euler[0]=phi, euler[1]=chi, euler[2]=omega. If u==0, v==0 or u and v are collinear, this just returns an array of zeros.

getEulerAngles

public static float[] getEulerAngles(Vector3D u,
                                     Vector3D v)
Return an array containing a set of "Euler angles" representing a rotation that takes the orthonormal basis vectors i,j,k into another set of orthonormal basis vectors u,v,n. Only the basis vectors u,v are taken as arguments since the "n" vector is calculated internally as u X v. "v" is then recalculated as n X u, in case v was not originally perpendicular to "u". All vectors will be normalized internally. The angles of rotation are to be applied as follows: 1. Rotate about the positive z-axis by phi 2. Rotate about the positive x-axis by chi 3. Rotate about the positive z-axis by omega NOTE: All rotations follow a right hand rule and the coordinate system is assumed to be right handed. Rotation angles are returned in degrees.

Parameters:
u - Vector giving the direction that the basis vector "i" maps to.
v - Vector giving the direction that the basis vector "j" maps to. In principle, this should be perpendicular to u, it at least must not be collinear with u.
Returns:
The Euler angles are returned in an array euler[], with euler[0]=phi, euler[1]=chi, euler[2]=omega. If u==0, v==0 or u and v are collinear, this just returns an array of zeros.

makeEulerRotation

public static Tran3D_d makeEulerRotation(double phi,
                                         double chi,
                                         double omega)
Make the cumulative rotation matrix representing rotation by Euler angles phi, chi and omega. This produces a matrix representing the following sequence of rotations, applied in the order listed: 1. Rotate about the positive z-axis by phi 2. Rotate about the positive x-axis by chi 3. Rotate about the positive z-axis by omega NOTE: All rotations follow a right hand rule and the coordinate system is assumed to be right handed. Rotation angles are specified in degrees.

Parameters:
phi - Angle to rotate about the +z-axis
chi - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +x-axis
omega - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +z-axis
Returns:
The cumulative rotation matrix omegaRz * chiRx * phiRz, which carries out these rotations, starting with rotation by phi about the z-axis.

makeEulerRotation

public static Tran3D makeEulerRotation(float phi,
                                       float chi,
                                       float omega)
Make the cumulative rotation matrix representing rotation by Euler angles chi, phi and omega. This produces a matrix representing the following sequence of rotations, applied in the order listed: 1. Rotate about the positive z-axis by phi 2. Rotate about the positive x-axis by chi 3. Rotate about the positive z-axis by omega NOTE: All rotations follow a right hand rule and the coordinate system is assumed to be right handed. Rotation angles are specified in degrees.

Parameters:
phi - Angle to rotate about the +z-axis
chi - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +x-axis
omega - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +z-axis
Returns:
The cumulative rotation matrix omegaRz * chiRx * phiRz, which carries out these rotations, starting with rotation by phi about the z-axis.

makeEulerRotationMatrix

public static double[][] makeEulerRotationMatrix(double phi,
                                                 double chi,
                                                 double omega)
Make the double precision rotation matrix representing rotation by Euler angles chi, phi and omega. This produces a matrix representing the following sequence of rotations, applied in the order listed: 1. Rotate about the positive z-axis by phi 2. Rotate about the positive x-axis by chi 3. Rotate about the positive z-axis by omega NOTE: All rotations follow a right hand rule and the coordinate system is assumed to be right handed. Rotation angles are specified in degrees.

Parameters:
phi - Angle to rotate about the +z-axis
chi - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +x-axis
omega - Angle to rotate (the rotated system) about the +z-axis
Returns:
The cumulative rotation matrix omegaRz * chiRx * phiRz, which carries out these rotations, starting with rotation by phi about the z-axis.
